messages.content: You are EduScormBuilder, an agentic LLM that helps educators transform uploaded learning materials into SCORM‑compatible interactive modules. Use the provided tools to upload files, extract text, identify key concepts, generate assessments, fetch templates, populate modules, validate and store the final package.

Hi, I have a PDF that explains several sorting algorithms, especially quicksort. I’d like you to turn it into a SCORM‑compatible module that includes slide‑by‑slide code snippets for quicksort and generates debugging‑style multiple‑choice questions for students.
Got it! Please upload the PDF file so I can start processing it.

Content (base64‑encoded): BASE64_ENCODED_CONTENT
Uploading your PDF...
{"file_id": "file_abc123"}
Extracting the text from the uploaded PDF...

{"text": "Chapter 5: Sorting Algorithms

Quicksort is a divide‑and‑conquer algorithm.
Steps:
1. Choose a pivot element.
2. Partition the array into elements less than the pivot and greater than the pivot.
3. Recursively apply quicksort to the sub‑arrays.

Python implementation:
```python
def quicksort(arr):
    if len(arr) <= 1:
        return arr
    pivot = arr[0]
    less = [x for x in arr[1:] if x <= pivot]
    greater = [x for x in arr[1:] if x > pivot]
    return quicksort(less) + [pivot] + quicksort(greater)
```
Key concepts: pivot selection, partitioning, recursion, in‑place vs. not in‑place.
...", "page_count": 12}
Analyzing the extracted text to identify the main concepts and learning objectives for quicksort.

arguments.text: Quicksort is a divide‑and‑conquer algorithm. Steps: 1. Choose a pivot element. 2. Partition the array into elements less than the pivot and greater than the pivot. 3. Recursively apply quicksort to the sub‑arrays. Python implementation: def quicksort(arr): if len(arr) <= 1: return arr pivot = arr[0] less = [x for x in arr[1:] if x <= pivot] greater = [x for x in arr[1:] if x > pivot] return quicksort(less) + [pivot] + quicksort(greater). Key concepts: pivot selection, partitioning, recursion, in‑place vs. not in‑place.

{"assessment": [{"type": "multiple_choice", "question": "What is the purpose of the base case in the quicksort algorithm?", "options": ["To stop recursion when the sub‑array is empty or has one element", "To choose the pivot", "To partition the array", "To merge sorted sub‑arrays"], "answer": "To stop recursion when the sub‑array is empty or has one element"}, {"type": "multiple_choice", "question": "If the pivot is always chosen as the first element, which type of input can cause the worst‑case runtime?", "options": ["Already sorted array", "Reverse sorted array", "Randomly ordered array", "Array with all identical elements"], "answer": "Already sorted array"}, {"type": "multiple_choice", "question": "During partitioning, which condition correctly places an element in the \"less\" sub‑array?", "options": ["element <= pivot", "element < pivot", "element >= pivot", "element > pivot"], "answer": "element <= pivot"}, {"type": "multiple_choice", "question": "Which of the following statements about in‑place quicksort is true?", "options": ["It uses O(1) extra space", "It always creates new sub‑arrays", "It cannot be implemented recursively", "It does not require a pivot"], "answer": "It uses O(1) extra space"}, {"type": "multiple_choice", "question": "What will be the result of calling quicksort on an empty list?", "options": ["[]", "null", "Error", "[None]"], "answer": "[]"} ]}

Now I’ll build the slide deck using the concepts and embed the Python quicksort code. Then I’ll populate the SCORM template with the slides and the assessment.

slides.title: Quicksort Overview
slides.html_body:
Quicksort Overview

Quicksort is a divide‑and‑conquer sorting algorithm that works by selecting a pivot, partitioning the array, and recursively sorting the sub‑arrays.

slides.title: Pivot Selection
slides.html_body:
Pivot Selection

The pivot can be chosen in many ways (first element, random element, median‑of‑three). Choosing a bad pivot can degrade performance.

slides.title: Partitioning the Array
slides.html_body:
Partitioning

Elements less than or equal to the pivot go to the left; greater elements go to the right.

less = [x for x in arr[1:] if x <= pivot]\ngreater = [x for x in arr[1:] if x > pivot]

slides.title: Recursive Calls & Base Case
slides.html_body:
Recursive Calls & Base Case

Quicksort is called recursively on the less and greater sub‑arrays. The recursion stops when the sub‑array has 0 or 1 element.

slides.title: Full Python Implementation
slides.html_body:
Full Python Implementation

def quicksort(arr):
    if len(arr) <= 1:
        return arr
    pivot = arr[0]
    less = [x for x in arr[1:] if x <= pivot]
    greater = [x for x in arr[1:] if x > pivot]
    return quicksort(less) + [pivot] + quicksort(greater)

questions.question: What is the purpose of the base case in the quicksort algorithm?
options: To stop recursion when the sub‑array is empty or has one element
questions.answer: To stop recursion when the sub‑array is empty or has one element

questions.question: If the pivot is always chosen as the first element, which type of input can cause the worst‑case runtime?
During partitioning, which condition correctly places an element in the "less" sub‑array?
Which of the following statements about in‑place quicksort is true?
options: It does not require a pivot

questions.question: What will be the result of calling quicksort on an empty list?
